page.lettertext:
fol.81r
May it please your good L. Upon conference had with
M
r
Barne-
velt
and with some others of
e State, for
e advancement of my
service, I see this message of her
Ma
tie
doth trouble them excee-
dingly. For they seeme very loath to returne a naked answear,
and to give her good content they pleade unabilitie. But their
greatest doubt is this, whether in this conjuncture (as they terme
it) and as the present state standeth, both with them and
the Enemie, and those
at now endevo
r
to drawe them to a peace
considering also this yeares contribution is not accorded by the
Provinces,
it were convenient to imparte to
e people her Ma
tie
demaundes. For they say they can doe nothing without their
approbation, for contenting of her Ma
tie
and to publish unto
them what her Hig
es
requireth, they holde it very dangerous in
this p
nt
concurrence of soe sundrie great and weightie affaires.
They have bin often together to determine upon it, but they
are at no conclusion. I expect every day when some shalbe depu-
ted to come in conference with me and by that as I thincke,
I shall ghesse somwhat neere, both how they will frame their p
nt
aunswear, and what successe in the ende I am lyke to have.
Coronel Stuart
hath bin with me, and in co
m
unication hath
declared that his coming to
e
States
is for no other cause,
but first to renewe an alliance between
e
King
and these
Contreis, such as hath bin established in former tymes: second-
ly to acquaint them very throughly with
e present Estate of
Scotland:
and then lastly to request their advise, together with
their succo
r
without proposing wherein, but according to their
power, and soe as they shall finde the necessitie of
e King, which
toucheth them in lyke manner, if his Ennemies should prevayle.
and this he pretendes to be a course, which the King is forced to
take. For saith he, sith he cannot be supported by the Q. of
England
by whome he sawe his Estate but slenderly regarded,
to whome should he seeke but to
e people of these Provinces?
Through the helpe of those discourses which I receaved of
S
r
Robert
Cecill
, I was stoared with good matter to aunswear his complaint
fol.81v
which he uttered notwithstanding without any passion, and with a
preface before, full of duetifull wordes of respect to her Ma
tie
.
Howbeyt I sawe by
at little, and by other conjectures, that he
with other phrases in other Company abroade. I have done w
at
I can to feele the States disposition, to gratefie the King, but
I can not yet perceave that they are bent therunto, not for want
of affection (for undoubtedly
at waye they are forwarde) but if
they will relieve him, it must be only with mony (for men
I am sure they can not spare) which if they had in their Cofers,
or could devise to come by it, I doe not doubt but some good
portion would be graunted her Hig
es
, and to content the Kinge
besides, there is noe manner of probablitie
at they will any waye
be able. It is also signified by
e Coronel unto me,
at to stren-
ghten the League between the King and these Contreis, he hath
in charge to motion a match, between the
Erle of Orchney
, and
the
La. Emeilie
Co. Maurices
sister, which I heare them saye heere
is labor loste, for
at
e Erles dwelling is farre of, and as it is
saide, he hath no assurance of
e
Orcades,
because they have bin
claymed by
e Kinges of
Denmarke,
and it was a late speeche of
the
Q. of Scotland
, that she hoped her sonne should enjoye
those Iles. Where your L. puttes me in mynde by a l
re
of
e
25 of
e last, of
e suite of
e
Marchants adventurers
, about
e
taring of their clothes, and of
e abuse of those of Middlebourgh;
about the Currancie of their monies: for this later point, I
have dealth therin heere, and also at Middleborgh, and it was
carefully followed by
M
r
Gilpin
before, who hath and will certe-
fie what reformation therin is intended by
e States. And soe
for
e former I doe but watch an opportunitie, to reco
m
end it with
the soonest. For now I am certaine, I should come out of season,
to cause them to assemble for a matter of that qualitie.
And where your L. would be informed of the nombers remay-
ning of
e English regiment in
e States paye, I finde by in-
quirie of their Co
m
issarie, by whome they were mustred very
lately,
at he reckened 900 or more very able and soldierlyke
fol.82r
men, and that of
e residue many are runne awaye: and many
gone with license, and also dyvers consumed with sickenesse
and in service. We are no longer now in doubt, but
at
the Castel, and towne of
Huy
or Hoy in
e Lande of Luycke,
are surprised, and kepte with 600 foote and 200 horse of this
Contrey:
Haranguieres
the Gouvernor of
Breda
co
m
aunding in
e
castel, and an other Cap
t
in the Towne. If
e place be so
stronge by nature, as every man reportes, or can be strenghtened
by Arte and industrie, beying situat, as it is, upon soe famous
a river, and in the middest of soe many riche Provinces, it will
undoubtedly be brought to yelde a large revenue, by meanes of
newe contributions and divers kindes of impositions,
at maye be
raised in tyme upon
e Contrey, and
e River. Moreover the
passadge too and fro, between the Enemie and
Italy,
will now in
a manner be closed up cleane, the sooner, through
e aide of
e
D. of Bouillon
, who hath his Armie there at hand, within 16
dutche myles. In effect it is thought
at
e taking of this place
will cause a great alteration in
e actions of this Contrey, and
I hope it will advaunce that which I am to negotiat.
The defeat of our horsemen, whereof I writte in my laste, hath
bin verified unto us, but there were no more, (as now we are ad-
vertised but 4 Cornets in all, and we have loste but 70 horse
which I thincke will prove a favorable reporte.
I doe also understand
at the States have a purpose, if they finde
upon triall, that Huy is stronge and tenable, to take and fortifie
some place about
e midde way, between it and Breda, which will
adde a great assurance to
e holding of the towne, and doe
e Enemie
more annoyance. The bishop of
Liege
hath sent his
Ambassadols hither, to expostulat this taking of Huy, beyng a
neutral place, but they have had no audience as yet.
The Scottish Kinge hath given Comission to
e Consul of
e Scottish
marchants residing in
Torvere
in
Zeland,
whom they other-
wise terme Conservator of their priviledges, to continue heere
as his Ambassador Ligger w
t
e States. His name is
fol.82v
Copie of my l
re
to my L. T
re
r Fe
b
14
[D
r
Birch's Memoirs Vol. 1 Page 209 [.]]
Robert Denniston
, a man brought up in the study of
e civill lawes
and in travell. It is advertised hither by
e Agent of the States
residing in Scotland, that
e King there of late hath sette his
moneis at a higher rate then their value, and hath withall
procured by his marchants out of Zeland ten thousand powndes
sterling to be conveyed unto him in coyne, which some interpret
heere, to be a special token of a great alteration lyke to ensue
knowing nothing besydes worth the wiriting to your L. I take
my humble leave.
